The passage details security vulnerabilities in Apple's iCloud linked to the theft of celebrities' private photos, attributed to third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple introduced a two-factor authentication (2FA) system to block unauthorized access, requiring a four-digit code (sent via SMS or the Find My iPhone app) alongside passwords. However, 2FA remains an opt-in feature, with experts urging Apple to make it the default. Users can bypass 2FA with a 14-character recovery key, though this poses risks if lost or stolen. Elcomsoft’s owner confirmed Apple’s updates now prevent their software from accessing iCloud backups, but security flaws persist, such as recovery key vulnerabilities. Apple plans to promote 2FA adoption and stronger passwords, while experts emphasize the need for default 2FA across tech companies. CEO Tim Cook highlighted the importance of user awareness in improving security.

The passage outlines campaign spending by UK political parties in the European elections: UKIP spent £2,956,737 (68p per vote), the Conservatives £2,980,815 (79p per vote), Labour £1,027,339 (26p per vote), the Lib Dems £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote, losing 11 of 12 MEPs), the Greens £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP £267,372. Total spending by the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087. All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 election.

The passage details two new signings for the Gulls football club. Centre-back Anderson, 27, joined after cancelling his Barrow contract by mutual consent; he has prior experience at Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, and could face his former club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, arrives from spells at Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson’s leadership despite his limited game time for his age and highlighted Keating’s youth and determination. The Gulls currently sit four points above the relegation zone, with only one win in their last six games.

The passage details the death of Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, who collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause as a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," noting such incidents are rare and can occur even in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite the rarity, the sport aims to better understand and prevent such events. Many Clouds had a history of overheating and post-race ataxia but had never previously collapsed and showed no such symptoms during this race. Trained by Oliver Sherwood and ridden by Leighton Aspell, the horse had previously won major races, including the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup. While questions arose about a potential link between his past overheating and his death, the report attributes his demise solely to the rare haemorrhage.

The passage details emotional farewell speeches by outgoing Scottish MSPs ahead of the 5 May election. Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved by addresses from veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond (SNP), both retiring. Salmond emphasized Scotland’s diversity over division, praised increased Holyrood powers under the Scotland Bill, and critiqued unfulfilled unionist pledges post-referendum, while adding humor about competing with the UK budget and Cheltenham races. He concluded with a valediction on public service. McNeil warned Holyrood to improve accountability and scrutiny, urging lessons from Westminster’s committee system. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bid farewell, jesting about Finance Secretary John Swinney’s mannerisms. All highlighted their contributions and reflections on parliamentary governance.

The passage outlines casting and production details for Disney's 2017 live-action *Beauty and the Beast*. Key points include: Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice. The role of Mrs. Potts (previously voiced by Angela Lansbury) is recast. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios, with a US release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will inform victims' relatives of its decisions regarding potential charges in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, which killed 96 football fans, at a meeting in Warrington. New inquests in 2016 ruled the deaths unlawful. Evidence files for 23 suspects were submitted to the CPS in January, split between Operation Resolve (15 suspects linked to the disaster's causes) and an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe (8 suspects related to police conduct post-incident). Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the tragedy, emphasized the families' long struggle and demand for accountability, acknowledging the meeting as a pivotal but emotionally complex step toward justice.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced repeated incidents of contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, being thrown over its walls, with a resident reporting four such events in two weeks. A former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver items directly to prison windows, though the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) denied evidence of drone activity at the site. The MoJ acknowledged ongoing challenges, stating staff work "extremely hard" to intercept contraband and noting new laws allowing up to two years' imprisonment for smuggling. The Justice Secretary is reviewing measures to address the issue, while the prison engages locals on safety concerns. Residents expressed unease but reported taking precautions like locking doors.

The passage details the trial of Brian Wright, 55, who struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright admitted hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. Blackburn, wearing appropriate safety gear, was assisting pedestrians when Wright’s vehicle failed to stop at a red light. She sustained severe head injuries and now requires residential care. Wright expressed remorse, acknowledging the impact on her family. The court heard conflicting accounts: Wright could not recall the traffic light’s status, while the prosecution asserted he ignored the red light. The trial continues.

The passage details middle-distance runner Laura Muir's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over competing at the Commonwealth Games in April due to exams in May. Despite disappointment at missing the event, she emphasizes completing her degree as a priority. Muir reflects on her recent performances at the World Athletics Championships, where she placed fourth (1500m) and sixth (5000m), achieving a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5000m. She expresses optimism about future competitions, including the World Indoor Championships in March and potential Olympic participation, while acknowledging the demanding balance between academics and athletics. The text also notes Hellen Obiri's victory in the 5000m at the World Championships, with Sifan Hassan securing third.

The passage details the ongoing investigation into the 2000 disappearance of 22-year-old Trevor Deely, last seen after a Christmas party in Dublin. A search of a three-acre site in Chapelizod near the River Liffey began, involving excavations expected to last weeks. A 2023 review by six detectives re-examined enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely talking to a man in black outside his workplace (Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street) and later being followed on Haddington Road. Authorities believe the unidentified man may hold key information and have renewed appeals for his identification, as he remains unknown despite footage released in April. Deely, from County Kildare, was returning to retrieve an umbrella when he vanished.

The passage highlights key tennis match outcomes and player contexts:  
1. **Del Potro** (ranked 165th after injury layoffs) defeated Stan Wawrinka in a four-set comeback match (3-6, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3). He faces Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next and expressed joy at his post-injury resurgence.  
2. **Andy Murray’s half of the draw** includes Del Potro and **Nick Kyrgios**, who overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-interrupted five-setter (6-7, 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4). Kyrgios will play Feliciano Lopez, who also rallied from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini.  
3. **Tomas Berdych** (10th seed) and **Jo-Wilfried Tsonga** (12th seed) advanced with straight-sets wins.  
4. Del Potro, a former world No. 4 and 2013 Wimbledon semi-finalist, is competing in his first Grand Slam since 2014 after three wrist surgeries.  
5. Kyrgios and Murray could meet in the last 16 if both progress.  

The summary focuses on match results, player comebacks, and tournament progression.

The passage details tensions and resolutions involving Tunisia and Morocco in the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON). Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 AFCON after disputing a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final against host Equatorial Guinea, which led to a 2-1 loss. Tunisia’s federation (FTF) criticized the referee’s choice but denied accusing Caf (Confederation of African Football) of corruption, instead arguing the official was unfit. Caf demanded an apology by March 2015 or risk disqualification, which Tunisia provided after negotiations with Caf president Issa Hayatou, resolving the conflict.  

Morocco, meanwhile, re-entered 2017 AFCON qualifying after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned Caf’s ban and reduced a $1m fine to $50,000. Morocco had been stripped of hosting the 2015 AFCON after refusing to host due to Ebola fears, leading Equatorial Guinea to step in with minimal preparation. Both nations expressed optimism about future participation, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive AFCON finals in 2017. The 2017 group stage saw Tunisia in Group A (Togo, Liberia, Djibouti) and Morocco in Group F (Cape Verde, Libya, Sao Tome).

McLaren, a historically dominant Formula 1 team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers’ titles, and 8 constructors’ championships, has experienced a prolonged decline since 2013. Once defined by eras of success—such as the 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost (15 wins in 16 races) and the 1998–99 dominance with Mika Häkkinen—the team has faced recurring cycles of triumph and collapse. Recent struggles stem from technical failures, including a flawed chassis (2013) and underperforming Honda power units (post-2015), despite retaining two world champions, Fernando Alonso and (until 2017) Lewis Hamilton. Scandals, like the 2007 "spy-gate" disqualification and 2009 "lie-gate" controversy, further damaged their reputation. Ron Dennis, who revitalized the team in the 1980s–90s, returned in 2013 but has yet to reverse the slump. Alonso rejoined in 2015, betting on Honda’s potential to secure his third title, while Dennis insists McLaren will eventually challenge Mercedes’ dominance. However, current results—targeting mid-grid positions and points—highlight a stark contrast to their legacy, leaving the team’s revival reliant on hope and incremental progress.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014. Police found alcohol was served past licensing hours (until 04:49 BST), leading to a three-month closure order. License holder Colleen O'Neill (43) and James Thomas (44) were charged with allowing illegal liquor consumption. A defense solicitor acknowledged poor compliance with licensing laws, noting the bar operated "well into the morning." The judge criticized O'Neill's "appalling record" but could not impose jail time, fining her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record (272) by hitting eight three-pointers, scoring 45 points, and leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Teammate Klay Thompson added 26 points, helping overcome a 13-point deficit. Elsewhere, the Chicago Bulls erased a 19-point halftime deficit against the Miami Heat, fueled by Pau Gasol’s 16 points and 15 rebounds, to win 89-78 and boost their playoff standing, while Miami’s struggles continued with Dwyane Wade’s poor shooting (4-20) and a 57-27 second-half deficit.

The passage details an encounter between Liverpool players (Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, Lazar Markovic) and Dutch YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen at Melwood. Initially presented as a competition winner meeting the team, van Velzen surprised the players by demonstrating his exceptional dead-ball skills during a mock session, leaving them impressed. Balotelli notably scored a successful free-kick after a poor first attempt. Van Velzen, known for his viral YouTube videos, humorously pretended to be an amateur fan, delighting in the players' reactions. The event concluded with van Velzen revealing Balotelli’s infamous "Why Always Me?" t-shirt from his Manchester City days.

The passage highlights that women with the **BRCA1 gene mutation** diagnosed with breast cancer can significantly reduce their mortality risk by undergoing **oophorectomy** (ovary removal), as exemplified by Angelina Jolie. Key findings from a Canadian study of 676 BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation carriers include:  
- Oophorectomy after breast cancer diagnosis reduces **breast cancer mortality by 62%** in BRCA1 carriers (but not BRCA2).  
- A **65% reduction in all-cause mortality** was observed overall, with the greatest benefit (73% lower death risk) in BRCA1 carriers who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis.  
- 20-year survival rate was 77.4% for the group, with ovarian cancer deaths occurring only in women who retained their ovaries.  
- The protective effect lasted **15 years post-diagnosis**, particularly for estrogen-receptor-negative breast cancer.  
- Experts recommend discussing oophorectomy as part of initial treatment for BRCA1 carriers, though further research is needed for BRCA2.  
- BRCA mutations increase lifetime breast cancer risk to 50–80%, with BRCA1/BRCA2 faults being more prevalent in Ashkenazi Jewish populations. Genetic testing is available for high-risk individuals.  
- Jolie’s personal experience underscores the procedure’s role in risk reduction without compromising personal identity.

A married couple, Derek (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by Amtrak Train No. 80 (the Carolinian) on Easter Sunday morning near Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on tracks owned by Norfolk Southern. The incident occurred shortly before 10 a.m. local time, with both pronounced dead at the scene. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City with 166 passengers, delayed its route for approximately 2 hours and 45 minutes; no passengers were injured, though one individual received treatment for illness during the delay. A local man, James Thompson, reported encountering the pair earlier, suggesting they may have lived in a homeless camp and used a grocery cart for belongings. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, with the Charlotte-to-NYC route typically lasting 13.5 hours. Authorities confirmed no further injuries or incidents related to the collision.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellín cartel member, worked as a DEA undercover informant for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s, aiding in high-profile prosecutions like those of drug lord Carlos Lehder and Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite being promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his service, Toro was denied citizenship and now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health, leaving him in the U.S. illegally. The DEA refused to assist him even after he publicized his plight, and he fears assassination if returned to Colombia. A former DEA handler provided $5,000 for medical care after the agency declined help, but Toro remains in legal limbo, unable to secure a green card, passport, or social security benefits. He asserts he has atoned for past crimes and demands the citizenship he was promised.

The U.S. internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly exploiting its newly introduced ".sucks" domain to demand exorbitant fees (up to $2,499/year) from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift, as well as major brands (e.g., YouTube, Visa, Bank of America), to prevent reputational harm from negative domains. ICANN approved the domain but faces backlash from an advisory panel (including Microsoft and eBay), which condemned the practice as a "predatory shakedown scheme." Vox Populi defends its actions as legal, claiming the domains allow companies to engage critics, while ICANN warns of potential contract breaches if regulators deem the tactics illegal. The domain will later be offered to the public for $10/year, a move critics argue coerces entities into paying higher fees preemptively.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby boy’s body was found in a pond in Norfolk in 1988. Police exhumed the body in 2023 during a case review, and DNA analysis linked the infant to a relative, leading to the unnamed woman. She admitted concealing her pregnancy, delivering the baby alone, and placing the stillborn child in the pond. Charges of infanticide were dropped after her explanation, though she remains under investigation for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, reburied in 2023 at St Peter’s Church in Weasenham St Peter, was named "Peter" by the coroner’s chaplain after the church. A charity supporting stillbirth families funded a headstone with the inscription "lost but then found." Police confirmed no foul play or third-party involvement, crediting DNA advances for solving the cold case. The investigation team expressed empathy for the mother while closing the decades-old case.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to compensate passenger Kristopher Hicks after Hicks suffered severe brain injuries by jumping from Young’s moving vehicle. In 2010, Young, suspecting Hicks (then 23) of planning to evade payment, drove him back to the taxi rank instead of his home, unlawfully detaining him. Hicks, fearing prolonged confinement, exited the car at over 20mph, sustaining life-altering injuries including epilepsy, cognitive impairments, and loss of smell/taste, requiring 24/7 care from his mother. The High Court ruled Young’s actions constituted unlawful imprisonment, awarding Hicks damages (estimated at 50% of the family’s claim, potentially hundreds of thousands of pounds) and £250 for imprisonment. The judge noted Hicks’ decision to jump was reckless but acknowledged Young’s conduct created significant risk. A 50% reduction in damages was applied due to Hicks’ contributory negligence. Both parties may appeal, with a final compensation amount pending.

The passage reports on severe weather events in Kansas and Missouri, including tornado sightings near Goddard (close to Wichita) and southwestern Kansas, with storms posing risks to communities. CNN meteorologist Chad Myers highlighted the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Missouri experienced potential tornado damage in Potosi, with reports of wind damage, flooding, hail, and fallen trees. Additional storms were forecasted for Thursday across the Midwest and southern Great Lakes. Social media posts illustrated storm impacts, such as hail and dark clouds. The National Weather Service and CNN affiliates contributed to the coverage.

The passage details Luke Rockhold's strategy and confidence ahead of his middleweight bout against Lyoto Machida in New Jersey. Rockhold, seeking his fourth straight win since a 2015 loss to Vitor Belfort, aims to dominate by adopting a "bull" approach against Machida's evasive "matador" style, cutting him off and exploiting his perceived weaknesses on the ground and in varied techniques. Rockhold emphasizes his versatility, physicality, and stamina, citing marathon training to chase Machida. Both fighters respect each other's skills but are confident in their strategies: Machida believes his technique can secure a win and earn a title shot, while Rockhold asserts his broader skill set and preparation. Both enter off recent victories (Rockhold over Michael Bisping, Machida over CB Dollaway) and view the fight as a path to challenging for the title. Machida claims readiness after an eight-week training camp, though Rockhold dismisses Machida's chances outside his striking.

The passage describes a 2023 incident in Fort Pierce, Florida, where an 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, accidentally performed a "belly landing" by failing to deploy the landing gear of his light twin-engine aircraft while approaching the Aero Acres residential airpark. The plane skidded on its belly, damaging its propellers and creating a loud, unforgettable scraping sound. Despite the impact, Georgaklis re-engaged the engines, took off again, and safely flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, accompanied by his dog. Witnesses captured the event, noting the pilot’s quick reaction to avoid a crash. The FAA is investigating, though human error (forgetting to lower the gear) is cited as the likely cause, rather than mechanical failure. Georgaklis, with 50 years of flying experience, avoided serious harm despite significant aircraft damage.

**Summary:**  
Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment in Yaya Touré's underwhelming performances this season but pledged to support the midfielder until the end of the campaign, dismissing calls for him to rest. Despite Touré's remaining two-year contract, *Sportsmail* reported City may consider offers for him in the summer as part of a squad overhaul following a poor season. The team, struggling with just 18 points from the last 39 available, faces West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany. Goalkeeper Joe Hart defended Pellegrini, asserting the players—not the manager—bear responsibility for their failures. Separately, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell against joining City, citing examples of players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who failed to secure regular playtime there, despite City’s interest in the 25-year-old left-back.

**Summary:**  
Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will remain in the UK after his seven-year Italian prison sentence for mafia association expired under Italian law. Convicted in absentia in 1999, his extradition was initially approved in February 2014 but halted after Italian courts ruled the sentence void in October 2014, as Italian law extinguishes penalties after a period exceeding double the sentence length. The European arrest warrant was withdrawn, pending final court approval in the UK. Rancadore’s legal team argued the conviction could no longer justify imprisonment, and UK prosecutors acknowledged administrative delays contributed to the outcome. Legal experts criticized the protracted, costly process, while the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) admitted procedural errors. Rancadore, who lived in the UK for over 20 years under a false identity, avoided extradition due to the expired sentence and ongoing health concerns. The Italian Supreme Court must still confirm the ruling, but the case highlights complexities in international extradition and legal time limits.

The passage details the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, where **Mr. Mole**, ridden by retiring jockey AP McCoy, is a 7-2 co-favorite alongside **Special Tiara** and **Sprinter Sacre** in a seven-runner field. Trained by Paul Nicholls, Mr. Mole will be McCoy’s final Grade One ride before his retirement, a decision he announced after winning with the horse at Newbury in February. Sprinter Sacre, trained by Nicky Henderson, will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to injured regular jockey Barry Geraghty. Other entrants include Mick Channon’s Somersby. McCoy’s final race schedule remains undecided until Friday morning.

The passage details the 1975 murder of 9-year-old Marcia Trimble by Jerome Sydney Barrett in Nashville. Her body was found 33 days later in a garage near her home, showing signs of strangulation, sexual assault, and physical trauma. Barrett, a repeat offender with prior prison terms (1974–2002), evaded justice for 33 years until DNA evidence from the crime scene linked him to the crime. Convicted in 2009 of second-degree murder, he received a 44-year sentence. Marcia’s mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, avoided viewing crime scene photos for decades on her then-husband’s advice but later sought them out, expressing regret and a desire for revenge. The case remained Nashville’s most notorious unsolved murder until Barrett’s conviction.

Rory McIlroy, a four-time major champion, is determined to win the Masters to complete his career grand slam, a feat achieved by only five players (Sarazen, Hogan, Player, Nicklaus, Woods). He considers winning at Augusta National "unthinkable" to miss, viewing it as a defining career goal. Despite a disastrous 2011 final round (80) that cost him the lead, he rebounded to win the 2011 U.S. Open and subsequent majors, crediting the collapse as a pivotal learning experience. With only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he acknowledges the challenge but remains confident in his ability to thrive at Augusta, which he calls a "sanctuary" from off-course distractions (e.g., his canceled wedding, legal disputes). McIlroy emphasizes focusing on process over legacy, aiming to win multiple green jackets starting with his first.

The passage highlights trending stories from the past week, including: four rainbows appearing in New York after heavy rain, captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis; a crackdown on exotic dancers at rural Chinese wakes; Robert Downey Jr.'s frustration during a personal-life interview; a lip-plumping trend (#kyliejennerchallenge) involving jar suction; a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past via film; a controversial bomb-themed prom-posal accused of racism; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in *Beauty and the Beast*; Johnny Depp’s unrecognizable role in *Black Mass*; a pregnancy announcement referencing *The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air*; and a military dad photobombing his son. All stories gained social media traction.

The passage highlights alarming data on fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) in England: 272 children were hospitalized in the past year due to FAS, though experts warn the true number affected by prenatal alcohol exposure is likely higher. World Health Organization research suggests 1 in 100 UK births (≈7,500 annually) may involve alcohol-related developmental, behavioral, or physical issues. Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome emphasizes the condition’s under-diagnosis and lifelong impact. A case study of 15-year-old Niamh Brown illustrates the syndrome’s severity, including developmental delays and dependency. Other risks of prenatal alcohol use include organ damage, cerebral palsy, and epilepsy. While the UK government advises no alcohol during pregnancy, Mitchell advocates stricter adherence to abstinence.

A former juvenile offender, Shaun Andrew Mckerry (nicknamed "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for repeatedly returning home after crimes), was jailed for six years after attempting to rob Shildon Post Office in County Durham. On March 15, the 31-year-old, masked and armed with an axe, demanded cash from a terrified employee. Shopkeeper Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him, causing chaos as they wrestled. Dhillon’s wife, Sam, struck Mckerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him while his face was revealed to security cameras. Police arrested Mckerry, who had a history of 80 arrests by age 15 and convictions for offenses including burglary and stealing 22 charity boxes while disguised as a woman. His criminal record, dating to age 12, earned him notoriety as a "one-man crime wave." The nicknames originated from his frequent arrests and tendency to return home post-crime.

Four Royal Navy sailors (Joshua Finbow, 23; Craig Stoner, 24; Simon Radford, 31; Darren Smalley, 35) face charges of gang rape and sexual assault causing bodily harm following an alleged incident on April 10 at a Canadian barracks in Nova Scotia after an alcohol-fueled party post-ice hockey game. The victim, a woman in her early 20s from Halifax, attended the party with a friend invited by Canadian servicemen. The accused appeared in a Dartmouth court, where bail conditions require them to remain in Nova Scotia, surrender passports, reside at the Stadacona naval base, continue Royal Navy employment, and avoid contact with the victim or six witnesses. They must return to court on May 27 and could face up to 14 years in prison if convicted. The British government is cooperating, allowing them to retain Navy pay, though their employment status remains unclear. Canadian authorities described the allegations as "serious" and "disturbing," with forensic tests pending and potential additional charges.

The passage details the experiences of Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, whose four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease affecting approximately 1 in 200,000 births globally (only 70 known cases). The condition causes red, scaly, "scalded" skin, severe dryness, and heightened infection risks, requiring constant moisturizing (e.g., Vaseline applied 2–3 times daily) and specialized care. Valerie faced public accusations of child abuse, including an incident where armed police confronted her in a store after a stranger mistook RJ’s symptoms for burns. She endures frequent ignorant remarks, bullying (often from adults), and social exclusion, such as being denied entry to a play center. Despite challenges, Valerie emphasizes RJ’s resilience and personality, describing him as "bubbly" and "adorable." Netherton’s syndrome, a severe form of ichthyosis, is genetic and often misdiagnosed due to its rarity. Valerie found support through a UK-based Facebook group for families affected by the condition, which helped her manage RJ’s care. The family continues to navigate the physical, emotional, and societal impacts of the disease, advocating for greater awareness to combat stigma.

The passage details the controversy and removal of Protein World's "Are you Beach Body Ready?" advertisements in London Underground. The ads, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked backlash for promoting unrealistic body standards, leading to a 50,000-signature petition, over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), and defacement by critics. Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters were removed after their three-week paid period ended, though they acknowledged public concerns and pledged to consider future similar ads cautiously. Protein World defended the campaign, dismissing critics as "irrational" and claiming the image was unaltered, while facing threats and a bomb scare. Public figures like Susanna Reid criticized the ad as "anxiety-inducing," while others, including Katie Hopkins, supported the campaign. The ASA is assessing complaints for potential action, and the company remains defiant, citing its goal to promote fitness despite the uproar. Sales of protein products in the UK have surged, projected to reach £358m by 2017. A protest in Hyde Park and widespread social media outrage further highlighted the divisive nature of the campaign.

The passage highlights rail firms' planned fare hikes, including an 87% increase on the London-Cotswolds route (from £33.30 to £62.40) starting May 17, sparking criticism from Prime Minister David Cameron and constituents. Cameron urged First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review the decision, despite his pledge to freeze fares in real terms. Labour also proposed capping price rises. Unregulated fares, which make up half of rail revenue, are being raised during allowed annual windows. FGW defended the hike, stating it aligns the route with other services and offers cheaper advance tickets. Other firms, like Virgin and London Midland, announced increases (e.g., 24.5% on Stafford-Liverpool returns), though Virgin claimed its overall fare rise (1.65%) was below industry averages. The hikes contradict pre-election promises of fare freezes, drawing passenger backlash.

**Summary:**  
John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier and retired HGV driver, was left permanently blind in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown through his front door by vandals in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred on April 18 around 11:20 PM as Young and his new wife, Elaine (54), sat writing wedding thank-you cards—just three weeks after their marriage. Thugs initially pelted stones at their living room window, prompting Young to confront them. A brick was then hurled directly at him as he opened the door, causing severe facial injuries. Despite emergency surgery, he lost vision in his left eye. The couple, who have no children and met 14 months prior, expressed shock and fear, stating they felt targeted despite no prior issues in the neighborhood. Police confirmed no clear motive, suggesting the attack may have been random "yob" behavior, and urged witnesses to come forward. The Youngs plan to relocate due to safety concerns.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, signed a one-year contract extension after recovering from leg injuries sustained in a 2013 road accident that claimed his father’s life and caused him to miss the 2014 season. Following ankle surgery, he returned to play during Derbyshire’s pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi and will be available for the 2015 season, committing to the club until the end of 2016. Derbyshire’s elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton’s resilience and work ethic, expressing confidence in his ability to perform strongly in the upcoming season.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma, a rare cancer affecting nerve cells, which had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. After enduring 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, he was declared cancer-free following a year of treatment. During radiotherapy, Harley wore a Ninja Turtle-themed superhero mask he decorated himself to feel brave, a gesture that inspired hospital staff and gained global attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon. His family, overjoyed by his recovery, hopes he will soon return to school full-time. Neuroblastoma, which affects fewer than 100 UK children annually, often presents vague symptoms like fatigue and bone pain and can spread to bones, lymph nodes, and other tissues. Harley’s resilience earned him Cancer Research UK’s Little Star Award, and he now represents the charity’s campaign to fund childhood cancer research.

The passage highlights Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, who is in demand from both the Republic of Ireland and England for international duty. Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa's manager, urges Grealish to prioritize cementing his place in Villa's first team rather than focusing on his international future. Sherwood praises Grealish's confidence and skill, noting his standout performance in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Grealish’s father, Kevin, echoes this advice, emphasizing club form first. Grealish, who has played for Ireland’s youth teams, remains undecided between the two nations, with a decision expected after the season. Sherwood compares his situation to Nabil Bentaleb’s choice between France and Algeria, stressing the decision should be personal. Grealish may participate in friendlies for both teams before deciding.

The passage highlights the variability and high costs of private jet landing fees at global airports, emphasizing unexpected hubs with the highest charges. Key points include:  
1. **Top airports with highest fees**: Japan dominates, with Haneda (Tokyo) at £4,559, Narita (Tokyo) at £3,728, and Kansai (Osaka) at £3,594 per landing. Other notable entries include Bristol Airport (UK, £2,929), Toronto (Canada, £3,461), Darwin (Australia, £3,059), and LaGuardia (New York, £2,630).  
2. **Industry scale**: Private jet travel is a $16.7 trillion (US) and $15.8 trillion (Europe) industry, with 2.5 million US and 705,000 European flights recorded in 2013.  
3. **Peak demand**: Major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix drive surges in private jet usage, with round-trip costs reaching up to $54,000 (e.g., New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl).  
4. **Popular routes**: Los Angeles to Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan-Rome (£5,880 one-way) are frequent short-haul routes.  
5. **Cost factors**: Fees reflect airport popularity, infrastructure demands, and efficiency (e.g., Haneda’s high punctuality despite 69 million annual passengers).  

The summary underscores that landing fees are a significant expense for wealthy travelers, with Japan’s airports leading in costs and events driving seasonal demand spikes.

The passage describes Cooper, a Labrador from Oregon, who rapidly consumes an ice cream cone during a McDonald's drive-thru visit with his owner, Katie Gallegos, and his smaller companion, Daisy. While Daisy takes small, polite licks, Cooper devours the treat in one bite, prompting Gallegos to prioritize Daisy’s portion first. The video of the incident, which has garnered over seven million views, sparked mixed reactions: some viewers found it amusing, while others criticized feeding dogs ice cream. Gallegos defended the practice, noting Cooper’s athleticism and health, and shared that her previous dog lived to 19 years old while occasionally eating ice cream. Another video shows the pair receiving a "pup-uccino" (whipped cream) at Starbucks, which Cooper similarly consumes entirely. Gallegos emphasizes portion control for Daisy due to her size and clarifies the treats are occasional and non-coffee-based.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock after a successful interim spell, signing a three-year contract. He joined the club as assistant to Allan Johnston in summer 2023 but took charge in February 2024 when Johnston departed. Since then, Locke has lost only one of seven games. A press conference is scheduled for Friday morning, and he has formally shaken hands with chairman Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims her autistic five-year-old son, Logan, was threatened with removal from Seminole County Elementary School due to his use of Doterra essential oils, which teachers said were distracting because of their scent (lavender, chamomile, sandalwood). Kemp asserts the oils, applied to Logan’s neck and head, help him stay calm and focused, and she refuses to stop using them despite a school board letter stating they caused a "problem." While the school initially warned of suspension, the Lake County district later clarified Logan would not be punished, citing his health needs. Kemp criticizes the policy allowing chemicals but banning natural scented products, vowing to continue advocating for her son’s use of the oils. Doterra, described as "beautifully fragrant," has not publicly commented.

A beachfront apartment complex, the Sandpiper, in Westhampton Beach, New York, was destroyed by a fire on a Wednesday afternoon. The blaze, which began around 3 PM, engulfed all 90 condos, melting paint off nearby buildings and collapsing the structure. Despite 12 fire crews and cranes attempting to combat the flames, firefighters could not enter the buildings. The fire, visible from three miles away, is under investigation, with initial speculation pointing to a possible origin near a parked car. The complex, used seasonally from May to November, housed residents like building manager Rob Taber, who lost all his belongings. Westhampton Fire Chief Ross Donneson noted offshore winds aided visibility during efforts. The cause remains undetermined.

The passage highlights Queen Elizabeth II's lifelong passion for horses, detailing her recent 88th birthday ride through Windsor Great Park on her Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, without a helmet—a preference she maintains due to her hair. It notes her early introduction to riding at age four with a Shetland pony, her ownership of notable horses like Betsy and Surprise, and her continued breeding of Fell and Highland ponies at royal studs. Despite reducing riding frequency due to a knee injury, she remains deeply involved with her stables, with her ponies now also ridden by grandchildren. The text also explores the Fell pony's history, tracing its lineage to Neolithic times, Roman and Viking use, industrial-era labor, and modern popularity as a family riding horse, emphasizing the Queen's role in preserving the breed through her Hampton Court stud.

A fatal altercation in Brisbane between 55-year-old Leon Yeaman and 28-year-old Phillip Pama, triggered by noise complaints, resulted in Yeaman’s death from a single punch to the head. Pama, a shift worker with no prior criminal record, confronted Yeaman outside their homes around 9 PM on Thursday after being disturbed during sleep. Yeaman, described as loud and erratic, was playing music loudly; Pama allegedly struck him "blindly" during a physical exchange. Yeaman died at the scene two hours later. Pama, granted conditional bail, must adhere to a curfew, surrender his passport, and report to police weekly. His defense cited Yeaman’s history of disruptive behavior, while neighbors portrayed Yeaman as generous but troubled. The case resumes in court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, plotted to torture and murder 15-year-old student Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) to hire a hitman, detailing plans to break the boy’s arms and legs, damage his kidneys, and make him suffer before killing him. Police conducted a sting operation with an undercover officer posing as a hitman, secretly recording Simonova’s instructions. After she handed over funds, she was arrested in her car and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison. The victim, Damian, expressed relief and hoped for her severe punishment. Simonova had previously showered him with gifts during their year-long relationship.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, emphasizes his daily communication with God, focusing on personal life rather than football, and maintains a clear separation between his professional and family life. A father of two, he highlights his family's experience with poverty and their involvement with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. Despite his competitive and emotionally charged professional persona, Mourinho asserts his self-perception as a good person, family-oriented and supportive of others, while acknowledging mistakes in his career. He attends church irregularly, primarily in Portugal, and avoids discussing football in religious contexts. The passage also notes his £25,000 fine for criticizing refereeing decisions and mentions his family's public appearances.

Bob Barker, the former longtime host of *The Price is Right*, returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1, 2023, temporarily replacing Drew Carey. At 91 years old, Barker hosted the initial segment featuring the game "Lucky Seven" before handing the reins back to Carey. Despite his absence since 2007, Barker demonstrated his signature ease and familiarity with the show’s format.

The passage reports that off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday for allegedly attempting to burglarize a residence on the 3200 block of D Street SE. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and property destruction. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin works in the Foreign Missions Branch, which supports U.S. diplomatic activities under the State Department. Court records indicate he was scheduled for arraignment Friday afternoon, but no attorney was listed. His arrest follows another incident involving a high-ranking supervisor placed on leave for alleged misconduct, which is under investigation by the Homeland Security Inspector General. Additionally, the Inspector General is probing a March 4 incident where two officials drove into a secure White House area after drinking. These events mark recent scandals affecting the agency’s reputation.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture close-up photos of a hungry lion in a safari park. Approaching within 10 feet of the lion while armed only with a camera, he lay on the ground near his open car door to take shots. The camera's shutter noise alerted the lion, prompting Saeed to flee rapidly as the animal lunged toward him. He described the encounter as a split-second decision to showcase the lion's "character and status," though he later admitted he would not repeat the risky act, calling it a "pretty close encounter."

The New York City Police Department released images of a distinctive tattoo—a heart with the name "Monique" on a ribbon beneath a rose—found on an unidentified woman (25–45 years old) discovered unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 in Brooklyn's Gravesend area. The woman, who had no ID, was found near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. Authorities seek public assistance to identify her and determine the cause of death, pending a medical examiner's report. Tips can be submitted via NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a self-sufficient, solar-powered two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009, as they could not afford traditional property. Over 1.5 years, they constructed a wood-and-steel home with a wood-fired stove, gas-powered utilities, and water from a nearby spring, costing approximately $25,000. The home, located in Nelson, New Zealand, features stained glass, a loft bedroom (used by their cat), and a design emphasizing natural materials and sustainability. They live nearly off-grid, with a $25 power bill, and plan to build another similar home in the future.

The passage highlights that kindergarten children who share iPads in class outperform peers in early literacy tests by around 30 points, according to a study by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University. The research involved 352 students in a Midwestern school district over an academic year, showing shared device use (vs. individual or no iPad use) enhanced learning through collaborative engagement with technology. Blackwell emphasizes that the benefit stems from collaborative learning *around* the devices, not mere collaboration alone, urging schools to rethink tablet integration in early education. This counters skepticism from the National Association of Head Teachers regarding technology use in non-IT classes. The findings are set to be presented at the International Communication Association’s 2025 conference in Puerto Rico.

The passage describes a two-legged piglet born without hind legs to farmer Ms. Duan in Sichuan, China. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," gained internet fame for balancing on its front trotters, wobbling but regaining balance while foraging. Despite its disability, it interacts normally with its four-legged siblings. Villagers flocked to see the animal after its birth. The piglet’s heartwarming story follows similar cases in China, such as a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that became a tourist attraction. The video highlights its determination and adaptability.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana in Avondale on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone’s car (No. 19, Italy) exiting the pit box on lap 25. Dracone spun, clipping Phillips’ leg, causing a cut requiring stitches; Phillips was treated and released. Dracone retired from the race, finishing 23rd. Rain prior to the race caused traction challenges for multiple cars.

A 32-year-old man, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his 29-year-old dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. CCTV footage captured Severiano dragging her limp body, slamming her head into concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, and shooting her five times at point-blank range with a handgun. He confessed to the attack, driven by jealousy over men looking at her, and later stole a neighbor’s car, crashing it during his escape. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle. Severiano admitted to the murder, citing accusations of her being a "slut" and claiming he acted to prevent other men from seeing her. Cicera belonged to a dance group called *Jaula das Gostozudas*. Severiano faces life imprisonment for the crime.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author known for her best-selling book *I Quit Sugar*, disclosed her severe mental health struggles, including anxiety that drove her to contemplate suicide. She described feeling isolated due to stress, thyroid disease, lack of family support, and societal pressures (e.g., not having a spouse or children). Wilson emphasized the link between depression and anxiety, calling anxiety the "new depression," and highlighted the rising impact of these issues on Australian women, citing statistics (1 in 3 will experience anxiety). She now accepts her anxiety but stresses the need for better understanding and support to address this crisis. Crisis resources (Beyond Blue, Lifeline) are mentioned for assistance.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old Oregon woman, was seven months pregnant when she attacked her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014 after finding her injecting heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the second-degree assault charge, citing her actions were “justified” under Oregon law permitting force against intruders who refuse to leave. The ex-girlfriend, described as “jealous and bitter,” had a history of drug use with Curtin’s boyfriend (the father of her child) and had allegedly harassed Curtin for years. Curtin, who faced a potential six-year prison sentence if convicted, gave birth in January 2015 and later reconciled with her boyfriend, though he is no longer involved in their child’s life. She now lives with her parents and has moved on from the relationship.

Gemma, a California-based pit bull, was filmed being tricked by her owner into eating a broccoli spear mixed with treats. After reacting with disgust and spitting out the vegetable, the incident humorously highlights her dislike for greens. The owner hopes the two children Gemma lives with avoid mimicking her behavior and instead develop a habit of eating vegetables. Additional videos showcase Gemma’s enjoyment of sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website, originally directing to its discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards page, was found rerouting visitors to a pornographic site. The error occurred because the domain registration for the awards page was not renewed after the program ended in 2011, allowing the pornographic site to take over the URL. HSBC removed the hyperlink upon discovering the issue, denied any affiliation with the external site, and assured the public its website remained secure. The bank issued a public apology on April 20, attributing the incident to a third-party website transition error.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were rescued from a house fire in Clinton after Marcus calmly provided 911 dispatchers with instructions for 11 minutes. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to smoke on the first floor, he reassured his sister, directed firefighters to enter through a black door via the back hallway, and helped them locate the room. Firefighters broke a window, rescued the siblings, and a firefighter gave Aaliyah his gas mask. Both were hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries, while three other family members escaped independently. Fire officials praised Marcus’s composure and actions as heroic.

The passage describes bioluminescent blue algae glowing along Australia's east coast, notably in Jervis Bay (NSW) and previously at Sydney's Manly Beach (2014). Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the phenomenon as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The glow stems from *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that preys on diatoms and produces luminescence as a defense mechanism. According to oceanographer Iain Suthers (UNSW), these blooms occur naturally in spring and autumn (90% of cases) and pose no cause for concern.

The passage discusses how new genetic tests, such as EndoPredict, can identify markers in breast cancer tumors to assess recurrence risk, potentially sparing patients from unnecessary chemotherapy. After surgery, tumor samples are analyzed, providing results within days to determine if the risk is low (as low as 5%)—a prognosis comparable to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. Chemotherapy, often routinely administered post-surgery despite severe side effects (e.g., hair loss, fatigue), may be avoided for low-risk patients. While tests cost around £2,500 and are mostly privately available, experts argue they could save healthcare costs by reducing chemotherapy use. Surgeons emphasize informed patient choices, contrasting past practices of widespread chemotherapy. A patient example highlights how the test enabled avoidance of chemo with minimal recurrence risk, supported by regular monitoring. NHS adoption is anticipated to improve accessibility.

The passage reveals that over 25 women in the Royal Navy were airlifted from ships (e.g., HMS Ocean, HMS Illustrious, and 18 others) due to pregnancy over nine years, with some evacuated via emergency medical flights. A Ministry of Defence "no touching" rule at sea suggests pregnancies likely occurred before deployment or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first female captain of a Royal Navy warship, was removed amid claims of a crew relationship, prompting an investigation. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990 (9% of personnel in 2014), with three becoming the first female submariners in 2014. Separately, 99 female UK troops were evacuated from Afghanistan (2006–2013) and 102 from Iraq due to pregnancy, as military rules bar pregnant personnel from war zones. Evacuations occurred on medical flights, though conception often predated deployment. The MoD states pregnant personnel are returned "at the first convenient opportunity" but are not required to take pre-deployment pregnancy tests.

A drone carrying traces of cesium, a radioactive material linked to nuclear reactors, was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence in Tokyo. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the substance, was found days after a court approved restarting two reactors at the Sendai nuclear plant—a decision opposed by many Japanese citizens due to safety concerns following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Authorities confirmed the cesium amount was not immediately harmful but highlighted fears of potential terrorism using drones, particularly at major events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japan currently lacks flight restrictions for drones around government buildings, prompting calls to review regulations. Prime Minister Abe was abroad during the incident. Investigations into the drone’s origin and intent are ongoing.

Lu Xincar, a security guard from Zhejiang, China, cares for his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer’s by taking her to work daily on his motorbike. After his father’s death and due to his wife working in another city and his son being in school, he ensures her safety by tying a sash around both their waists during the 4-kilometer, hour-long commute. His mother, prone to getting lost, is given a room at his workplace (a bank) to prevent wandering. Lu emphasizes his duty to reciprocate her lifelong care, stating, “I was an apple in my mum’s eye, and now she’s my apple.” His actions, driven by love and necessity, highlight his commitment to her well-being.

The passage highlights a significant rise in heavy and binge drinking among Americans from 2005 to 2012, with heavy drinking increasing by 17.2% and binge drinking surging most sharply among women. Key findings include:  
- **Definitions**: Heavy drinking is ≥1 drink/day (women) or ≥2 drinks/day (men); binge drinking is ≥4 drinks (women) or ≥5 drinks (men) in one occasion.  
- **Gender Trends**: Women drove the increase, with their binge drinking rates rising over seven times faster than men’s nationally. In Santa Clara County, CA, female binge drinking rose 36% (2002–2012) versus 23% for men.  
- **Geographic Variation**: In 2012, Menominee, WI, had the highest binge drinking rate (36%), while Madison County, ID, had the lowest (6%). Esmeralda County, NV, had the highest heavy drinking rate (22%), and Hancock County, TN, the lowest (2%).  
- **Impact**: Alcohol-related deaths totaled 88,600 in 2010, costing $220B annually. Treatment centers report rising demand, though stigma and perceived control deter many from seeking help.  
- **Causes**: Shifting social norms (women drinking more like men), affordability (alcohol prices dropping in real terms), increased advertising ($3.45B spent in 2011), and relaxed alcohol policies (e.g., weakened "blue laws").  
- **Data Source**: Analyzed 3.7 million adults via the CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System.  

The study underscores a public health concern exacerbated by cultural, economic, and policy changes.

The passage highlights concerns from UN officials and the World Health Organization (WHO) that caesarean sections (C-sections) are being overused in England, endangering women and babies. Key points include:  
- Current C-section rate is over 25% (more than double since the 1990s), far exceeding the WHO-recommended 10-15%.  
- Non-medical factors, such as maternal anxiety (tokophobia), drive some planned C-sections, despite WHO warnings of risks like infections, complications, and higher costs (£2,369 vs. £1,665 for natural birth).  
- WHO criticizes unnecessary C-sections for causing health risks and diverting resources, contradicting NHS guidelines that permit the procedure without medical justification.  
- Factors like prior complicated births, maternal age over 40, or conditions like diabetes may warrant C-sections, but WHO stresses underestimation of risks and the need for medical necessity.  
- Research indicates 10% of C-sections lead to infections, underscoring the WHO’s call for stricter adherence to medical need.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a $800,000 summer home on Martha’s Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner’s belongings (including furniture, a grill, lamps, and a painting) in a yard sale. Charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, she claimed ownership of the house when confronted by owner Mark Conklin, then fled in a gray Nissan truck. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket and arrested her later attempting to re-enter. Authorities are seeking the return of stolen items and warn recipients they may be entitled to restitution. Her next court date is May 14.

The passage details how Bella Crooke from Melbourne recovered her lost iPhone after it was handed to Albury Police Station (on the NSW-Victoria border). Police, finding the unlocked phone, humorously posted selfies and puns on her Facebook page to locate her, including photos of the phone in a holding "cell" and messages like "ready to be released early for good behaviour." Bella, who lost the phone at a friend’s birthday party, retrieved it without needing to provide her name, as officers recognized her from her Facebook profile. Friends praised the police’s humorous approach, which included texting updates to her contacts. Bella later added a password to her phone, expressing gratitude for the lighthearted yet effective recovery effort.

The passage describes a tragic incident in South Africa's Isimangaliso Wetland Park where a five-day-old baby hippo was fatally mauled during a fight between two adult male hippos. The calf, caught in the "firing line," was thrown into the air and dragged underwater by one of the males, with its mother helpless to intervene despite attacking the aggressor. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the event, noting the mother had earlier tried to shield the calf from younger hippos but stayed with the herd during the fight. The calf died hours later; the attackers' intent (aggression, play, or jealousy) remains unclear.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is listed for £575,000—far below local market rates—but with only three years remaining on its lease. Located in the exclusive Egerton Place, the 1,990 sq/ft property requires modernization and offers no guarantee of lease extension, which could cost £3.35–£4.5 million for 90 years. If extended, its value might rise to £6 million. A second, larger maisonette (2,500 sq/ft) nearby is priced at £595,000 with similar lease terms. Both properties, owned by the Welcome Trust, are rare due to their short leases and historic architecture. Agents note high buyer interest but warn of steep extension costs, with one expert calling it a "quirky" opportunity for developers or short-term renters. The freeholder’s identity and lease negotiation complexities add risk, as properties with such short leases are uncommon in Knightsbridge.

Starbucks experienced a widespread computer outage on a Friday evening, affecting point-of-sale systems at 8,000 U.S. and Canadian stores. The glitch, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, disrupted credit card transactions and forced some locations to close early or give away free drinks and baked goods. While many customers shared excitement on social media about the impromptu giveaways, other stores shut down to avoid further losses. The company resolved the issue by Saturday, resuming normal operations, and apologized for the inconvenience. The outage occurred shortly after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

The passage reveals that rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, are being used by terrorists for radicalization and training, according to DC Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Individuals involved engage in "seemingly ordinary activities" but have hidden motives. Historical examples include extremists trained in the Brecon Beacons (linked to Abu Hamza in 1998), 7/7 bombers visiting North Wales in 2005, and a 2010 Al-Qaeda-inspired plot by Cardiff men. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied at the European Institute of Human Sciences in Wales, established by Iraqi clerics. DC Jones emphasized that terrorism is not confined to cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence in addressing such threats.

A rare Omura's whale, previously thought extinct, was discovered washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first WA sighting and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, DNA confirmed the 5.68m juvenile female as an Omura's whale, a species scientifically described in 2003 and typically found in tropical/subtropical waters like Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Notable features include a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass was buried for future skeleton recovery, aiding research and potential museum display. The discovery is significant for improving field identification and understanding the species' distribution.

The passage critiques gender bias in leadership through the lens of hormonal arguments against female candidates, exemplified by Cheryl Rios' claim that women's hormones disqualify them from leadership. It counters this by highlighting male leaders' hormone-driven risks (e.g., Bush's Iraq War) and studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The text underscores systemic workplace bias against women, citing disparities in corporate representation and biased perceptions (e.g., male professors labeled "geniuses," women as "nice"). It argues equality benefits society economically and socially, urging action against stereotypes, while noting Hillary Clinton's unique challenges as a female candidate. The piece concludes by dismissing Rios' views as outdated, referencing Canada's female prime minister to underscore the fallacy of her claims.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, renowned for roles in *All Creatures Great and Small* and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 antiques from his collection to downsize his home. The £100,000 auction includes items reflecting his passions for military history and literature, such as a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (commissioned in the 1960s), a medieval longbow, furniture, art, books (some 17th-century), and historical artifacts. The sale, handled by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, features 238 lots, including a portrait of Hardy with a longbow and a painting of Alfred the Great. Hardy, a former Oxford student of Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, authored works on the longbow and contributed to the *Mary Rose* shipwreck project. Despite sadness over parting with his collection, he hopes new owners will cherish the items. A celebrated Shakespearean actor and friend of Richard Burton, Hardy later reached broader audiences via *Harry Potter* (as Cornelius Fudge) and retired from stage acting in 2013 after a fall but continues television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man with a history of mental illness and prior criminal charges, is a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was discovered in their Winter Garden home after a well-being check. He failed to attend a supervised visit with his son on the same day of the murder, prompting police involvement. Neighbors speculate that stress from ongoing divorce proceedings and recent adverse legal paperwork may have triggered the crime. Shemansky, who was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication, had a history of bipolar disorder, prior involuntary psychiatric commitment, and a domestic violence injunction filed by his estranged wife. Authorities recovered the unidentified murder weapon but have not disclosed details of the killing method. His mother had reportedly tried to prevent him from attending the visit, fearing legal repercussions. His wife is preparing for his potential return, and police urge the public to report his whereabouts.

The city of Eugene, USA, was awarded the 2021 IAAF World Championships without a competitive bidding process, as the IAAF Council deemed it a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the U.S. for the first time. This decision followed Eugene's unsuccessful bid for the 2019 championships, which were granted to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the collaboration of public and private sectors, the U.S. Olympic Committee, NBC, and public enthusiasm as key factors. The IAAF bypassed its standard procedure, citing the need to capitalize on a rare chance to expand the sport in a key market. A similar non-competitive award occurred for the 2007 Osaka championships.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger lured Hassan into a "honey trap" after meeting him at a London casino, exploiting his trust to facilitate a robbery. After Hassan showered her with gifts and money, Granger allowed her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson (28), and accomplice Nicholas Chandler (29), to attack Hassan at his flat. The pair bound and fatally kicked him during a violent robbery to steal his hidden winnings. Granger was convicted of manslaughter (not murder) by a majority verdict, while Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum 36-year term. All three were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan. The court heard Hassan, known for keeping large sums of cash at home, was targeted as a "soft target" due to his lifestyle. Granger’s defense cited her manipulation by Jackson, but the judge condemned her deceit and lack of compassion. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked," with Hassan found dead, bound and drowned in his blood, after the trio stole £3,000, a TV, and his phone. Police linked them via phone records and CCTV footage.

The passage highlights Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fàbregas's recurring late-season decline in form, evidenced by his poor performance in Spain's 2-0 loss to Holland and a drop in Premier League assists (from 15 by mid-January to just one in his last five games). Barcelona previously noted his consistent post-Christmas slumps, and despite a strong start to the season, fatigue from a demanding campaign has reduced his impact. While Chelsea manager José Mourinho hopes for a resurgence to secure the Premier League title, Fàbregas's ability to revive his form—particularly against teams he previously excelled against—remains critical for both his pursuit of Thierry Henry's assist record and Chelsea's title ambitions.

West Ham is nearing a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with the club’s academy after joining from Montego Bay United. The talented prospect, linked to multiple European clubs and considered one of the Caribbean’s top emerging players, has also attracted interest from Belgian teams. Separately, West Ham announced plans to offer the cheapest Premier League season tickets at their Olympic Stadium (from £289) for the 2016-17 season, aiming to fill its 54,000-seat capacity.

The passage details the police dropping an investigation into a violent assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, just three months after the attack. Lane was severely beaten by masked protesters armed with iron bars during a hunt using an artificial scent. Despite evidence including a video, suspect photos, witness names, and car registration numbers provided to Wiltshire Police, authorities closed the case due to "insufficient evidence." Lane condemned the decision as "pathetic," citing lost trust in police, while supporters criticized the lack of accountability for attackers wearing face coverings. The assailant’s face was captured on video but remains unidentified. Lane suffered concussion, broken teeth, memory loss, and incurred dental costs. Hunt supporters and witnesses, including Karen Fieldsend and James Cameron, expressed outrage, arguing rural crimes are overlooked. The Countryside Alliance campaigns to ban face coverings to aid justice. Police confirmed the case is "undetected" but may reopen if new evidence emerges.

The passage details the life and death of Adam Gadahn (also known as Azzam the American or Abu Suhayb), a U.S. citizen and prominent Al Qaeda member. Key points include:  
- Gadahn, born in 1978, converted to Islam in 1995, moved to Pakistan in 1998, and became Al Qaeda’s chief English-language propagandist, appearing in videos threatening attacks and urging lone-wolf violence.  
- He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to terrorism, featured on the FBI’s “Most Wanted Terrorists” list, and killed in a U.S. counterterrorism strike in January (year unspecified, but context implies 2015).  
- The same operation likely killed Ahmed Farouq (another U.S. Al Qaeda operative) and resulted in the deaths of U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto.  
- Gadahn criticized U.S. leaders, tore up his U.S. passport, and advocated overthrowing governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. His 2011 letter on Al Qaeda media strategy was found in Osama bin Laden’s compound.  
- He married an Afghan woman, had at least one child, and remained active until his death, with his final video released in September 2014.

The passage highlights the rise of five-year-old Chinese basketball prodigy Mai Zizhuo, who gained viral fame through a video showcasing his exceptional skills, including dribbling two basketballs and scoring hoops since age two and a half. His talent has captivated basketball enthusiasts in China, drawing comparisons to NBA star Yao Ming. Online reactions range from disbelief and praise to humorous self-deprecation, with netizens questioning his parentage and expressing awe at his abilities. The video, reported by *People's Daily Online*, underscores societal fascination with child prodigies in China.

The passage details Tom O'Carroll, a former key member of the 1970s–80s paedophile advocacy group PIE (which sought to legalize child sex and incest), joining the media reform group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, previously jailed for "corrupting public morals" and linked to the NCCL (which lobbied to lower the age of consent to 10), attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament on February 25 to push for state-regulated press oversight as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. His involvement, revealed via a blog post, has caused embarrassment to Hacked Off, which claims its events are open to the public. The rally was chaired by John Cleese.

The passage describes a fashion show held at Bondi's drained Icebergs Club pool during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event showcased Ten Pieces, a unisex lifestyle brand by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, featuring a capsule collection of ten items designed to be styled in 20 ways for day-to-night wear. Models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop, with guests enjoying food, drinks, and sunny weather (28°C). The androgynous, monochrome designs attracted onlookers from the club’s balconies, the beach, and nearby roads, blending high fashion with the iconic beach setting.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, interacting with a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Separately, he announced his upcoming fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation after previously facing pressure to face British rival Kell Brook in June. Khan revealed he had already been negotiating the Algieri bout, despite prior links to potential matches with Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

The passage details the removal of Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name from an Israeli memorial honoring soldiers and terrorism victims after his family and the organization Almagor protested. Abu Khdeir, 16, was murdered by three Israelis in a hate crime in July. His inclusion sparked objections: his father rejected associating his son with "soldiers of the occupation," while Almagor argued his death was a "rogue attack," not terrorism. Following complaints, Israel's National Insurance Institute removed his name from the memorial wall and website. Almagor threatened to withdraw other victims' names if the removal didn't occur. A trial for the suspects in his killing began in January.

The passage describes a video by California-based YouTuber Lionel Hutz featuring his young son repeatedly attempting to use the family cat as a pillow. The boy chases the cat in the garden, lies on its belly while it grooms itself, but the cat immediately moves away each time. After three attempts, the cat exits indoors, seemingly annoyed. A follow-up clip shows the pair reconciling, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats. Key elements include the boy’s persistence, the cat’s initial tolerance and eventual frustration, and the lighthearted resolution.

The passage details a Philadelphia police corruption trial where former drug dealer Robert Kushner, 32, testified against six ex-police officers accused of crimes like extortion and robbery. Kushner, who coached at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, lost his job after his past as a marijuana dealer and subsequent arrests (2007 charges expunged, 2011 probation, 2008 DUI) became public. He claimed officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana during his 2007 arrest, a revelation to the school, which had hired him after a clean background check in 2010. Kushner asserted he has moved past his past and expressed regret, while the defense dismissed the government's case as relying on "19 lying drug dealers." The trial highlights tensions between witness credibility and allegations of systemic police misconduct.

A chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, producing paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical, experienced an explosion after an oil leak at an oil storage facility on Monday night, injuring six people (five from broken glass). Over 600 firefighters contained the blaze, with no reported toxic chemical spills. Residents near the plant reported hearing the blast and sharing photos online. This follows a prior 2013 explosion at the site with no casualties. The plant, initially planned for densely populated Xiamen, was relocated to its current remote location after 2007 public protests over pollution concerns. PX plants in China have repeatedly sparked illegal protests, some violent, in recent years.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland U21 international, defies Premier League referees' requests to pull up his socks, adhering to a lifelong superstition. He wears his socks low, using children's shinpads (making them appear absent), and insists he will not change despite warnings. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, a match he described as a tough but valuable debut in a relegation battle. He expressed gratitude for the manager's trust and aims for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, suffers from "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and a source familiar with her condition. She does not react to visitors or familiar voices, her eyes do not track movement, and she has a tracheostomy. While Bobby Brown claimed his daughter is "awake" and watching him, contradicting earlier reports, the family's attorney stated her condition has improved enough to leave ICU and begin rehabilitation, though her long-term quality of life remains uncertain. Doctors indicate she may live a long life, but her recovery trajectory will take years to determine. Family members, including Bobby Brown's wife Alicia Etheredge-Brown, emphasize the rehabilitation process will be "long and hard."

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup semifinal after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki (4-6, 7-6, 6-3) and Svetlana Kuznetsova won her singles match in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with 13 double faults, while Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved costly.
